importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, reflecting the conclusion of Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season and the culmination of key events such as dramatic comebacks and quarterback performances.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe covers the first seven weeks of the 2025 NFL season, during which 26 lead changes in the final two minutes occurred—a historic record—highlighting the unpredictability and volatility of outcomes.

keyTakeAways: The NFL season has seen unprecedented late-game comebacks, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation in the first seven weeks, the most in NFL history.

Denver Broncos overcame a 19-point deficit against the New York Giants in the fourth quarter, becoming the first team in NFL history to reverse a shutout after leading by 18 points or more in the first three quarters.

Second-year quarterback Bo Nix delivered a breakout performance, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two scores, and ultimately completing a game-winning field goal as time expired, breaking a long-standing defensive record.

Drake Maye of the New England Patriots achieved a historic milestone by setting a franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate, surpassing Tom Brady’s previous record of 88.5% from 2009, and becoming the first player in Super Bowl era to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game.

The Miami Dolphins and New York Jets suffered major losses, prompting quarterback benchings: Tua Tagovailoa was replaced by rookie Quinn Ewers after three interceptions and a touchdown return, and Justin Fields was benched at halftime after a poor first half, replaced by Tyrod Taylor.

The Green Bay Packers defeated the Arizona Cardinals with a final-quarter touchdown and a late turnover on downs, aided by a dominant performance from defensive player Micah Parsons, who was traded from Dallas Cowboys to Green Bay.

The article highlights the instability and volatility in quarterback roles, including high-profile benchings due to poor performance, underscoring the pressure on young players and coaching decisions.

namedEntities.name: Bo Nix
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Second-year quarterback of the Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Nix led the Broncos in a historic comeback, becoming the first team in NFL history to overcome a 19-point deficit after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters, and set up a game-winning field goal with 37 seconds left.

namedEntities.name: Drake Maye
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Quarterback of the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate and became the first player in Super Bowl era to achieve 90% completion, over 200 passing yards, and over 50 rushing yards in one game.

namedEntities.name: Tom Brady
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former quarterback of the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His previous franchise record of 88.5% completion rate, set in 2009, was broken by Drake Maye in Week 7 of the 2025 season, signaling a shift in quarterback excellence in the Patriots' new era.

namedEntities.name: Tua Tagovailoa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He threw three interceptions in a loss to the Cleveland Browns, including one that was returned for a touchdown, leading to his benching in favor of rookie Quinn Ewers.

namedEntities.name: Justin Fields
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Quarterback of the New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He struggled in the first half against the Carolina Panthers, going 6-of-12 for 46 yards and 22 rushing yards, leading to his halftime benching and replacement by Tyrod Taylor.

namedEntities.name: Micah Parsons
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Defensive player traded from Dallas Cowboys to Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Parsons was dominant throughout the game, including a crucial sack on Arizona’s final drive, and played a pivotal role in the Packers' 27-23 win over the Cardinals.

namedEntities.name: Mike Vrabel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head coach of the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was previously fired by the Tennessee Titans, and his return to a victory with the Patriots in his first game against them since being fired, shows a significant shift in team dynamics and coaching success.

namedEntities.name: Quinn Ewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Seventh-round rookie quarterback of the Miami Dolphins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He entered the game as a replacement for Tua Tagovailoa after a disastrous performance, marking a turning point in the Dolphins' season and reflecting the urgency of coaching decisions.

namedEntities.name: Tyrod Taylor
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Backup quarterback of the New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He replaced Justin Fields in the second half and improved the Jets' performance, but still threw two costly interceptions, showing limited effectiveness despite being given the opportunity.

namedEntities.name: New York Giants
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team that lost to the Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Giants’ rookie quarterback Jaxson Dart led a scoring drive, but the Broncos’ comeback in the fourth quarter dramatically shifted the outcome of the game.

namedEntities.name: Arizona Cardinals
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team that lost to the Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Led by backup quarterback Jacoby Brissett, the Cardinals needed a touchdown on their final drive to win, which failed due to defensive pressure from Micah Parsons.

namedEntities.name: New England Patriots
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team with a record-breaking performance by Drake Maye
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Patriots' win over the Tennessee Titans marked a new era in franchise history, with Maye setting a franchise record and signaling a shift in quarterback excellence.

namedEntities.name: Cleveland Browns
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team that defeated the Miami Dolphins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Browns' win was a significant setback for the Dolphins, contributing to the team’s 1-13 record and the eventual benching of Tua Tagovailoa.

namedEntities.name: Carolina Panthers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team that defeated the New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Panthers' victory over the Jets, which occurred despite losing starting quarterback Bryce Young to injury, highlighted team resilience and competitiveness.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Rams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team that played in London and lost to the Jacksonville Jaguars
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The game in London highlighted the global reach of the NFL and the competitive intensity even in international venues.

namedEntities.name: Tennessee Titans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team that lost to the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Titans’ loss to the Patriots, where Maye had a record-breaking performance, emphasized the rise of new quarterback stars in the league.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season was defined by dramatic comebacks and pivotal quarterback performances. The Denver Broncos stunned the New York Giants by reversing a 19-point deficit to become the first team in NFL history to overcome a shutout after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters. Second-year quarterback Bo Nix delivered a breakout performance, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, culminating in a game-winning field goal. In a separate highlight, New England Patriots’ Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate and became the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game. Meanwhile, the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets suffered devastating losses, leading to the immediate benching of Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields, respectively. The Packers also defeated the Cardinals with a final-quarter touchdown and defensive pressure from Micah Parsons, who made a key sack on Arizona’s final drive. The season continues to reflect volatility, with record-breaking lead changes and shifting quarterback roles signaling a dynamic and unpredictable NFL landscape.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
